input: "<businessRuleTask id=\"businessRuleTask\" name=\"Business Rule Task\"/>"
output: "A Business Rule Task provides a mechanism for the process to provide input to a Business Rules Engine and to get the output of calculations that the business rules engine might provide. The input/output specification of the task will allow the process to send data to and receive data from the Business Rules Engine."

input: "<task id=\"taskWithParallelMI\" name=\"Task with Parallel Multi-Instance\"><multiInstanceLoopCharacteristics isSequential=\"false\" /></task>"
output: "A Parallel Multi-Instance Marker is used to represent an activity that can be executed as multiple instances performed in parallel. The number of instances will be determined through a condition expression that is evaluated at the start of the activity. All the instances will start in parallel and each instance can have different input parameters. The activity, as a whole, is completed after all the instances are completed. However, another expression, if it becomes true, will stop all instances and complete the activity."

input: "<sendTask id=\"sendTask\" name=\"Send Task\" />"
output: "A Send Task is a simple task that is designed to send a message to an external participant \n(relative to the process)"

input: "<task id=\"taskWithSequentialMI\" name=\"Task with Sequential Multi-Instance\"><multiInstanceLoopCharacteristics isSequential=\"true\" /></task>"
output: "A Sequential Multi-Instance Marker represents an activity that is similar to a Parallel MultiInstance activity, but its instances will be \nexecuted in sequence. The second instance will wait until the first instance is completed and so on."

input: "<subProcess id=\"adhocSubProcess\" name=\"Adhoc Sub-Process\"><adHoc>true</adHoc></subProcess>"
output: "The Adhoc Marker is a tilde symbol and used to mark a Sub-Process for which the normal sequence patterns are relaxed and its activities can be performed in any order at the discretion of the users. Tasks can start any time without any direct dependency on other tasks"

input: "<textAnnotation id=\"annotation\" text=\"Annotation\" />"
output: "An Annotation Marker is a mechanism for a modeler to provide additional text information (i.e., notes) for the reader of a BPMN diagram. Annotations can be connected to other objects \nthrough an Association (see above)."

input: "<association id=\"association\" sourceRef=\"sourceId\" targetRef=\"targetId\" />"
output: "An Association is represented by a dotted line, which may have a line arrowhead on one or both ends, and is used to associate text \nand other artifacts with flow objects."

input: "<callActivity id=\"callActivity\" name=\"Call Activity\" />"
output: "A Call Activity is a type of activity within a process. It provides a link to reusable activities: for example, it will call a task into the Processor another Process"

input: "<callActivity id=\"callActivity\" name=\"Call Activity\" calledElement=\"processId\" />"
output: "A Call Activity is a type of activity within a process. It provides a link to reusable activities: for example, it will call a task into the Processor another Process"

input: "<choreographyTask id=\"choreographyTask\" name=\"Choreography Task\" />"
output: "A Choreography Task represents a task or work performed by one or more participants in a BPMN choreography diagram. A Choreography Task is an atomic Activity in a Choreography . It represents a set of one (1) or more Message exchanges. \nEach Choreography Task involves two (2) Participants. The name of the Choreography Task and each of the Participants are all displayed in the different bands that make up the shape?s graphical notation. There are two (2) or more Participant Bands and one Task Name Band."

input: "<subProcess id=\"collapsedSubProcess\" name=\"Collapsed Sub-Process\" isExpanded=\"false\">"
output: " This attribute indicates that the sub-process is collapsed, meaning its details are hidden within the main process diagram. It typically includes a name attribute to label the sub-process. Collapsed sub-processes are used to improve the readability of a BPMN diagram by simplifying complex subprocesses, and they can be expanded to show the detailed activities when needed."

input: "<dataObjectReference id=\"collectionOfData\" name=\"Collection of Data\" />"
output: "A Collection of Data Objects represents a collection of data elements related to the same data entity (e.g., a list of order items)"

input: "<complexGateway id=\"complexGateway\" name=\"Complex Gateway\" />"
output: "Represents a decision point with more complex or ad-hoc routing logic, typically defined using additional conditions and rules.The Complex Gateway defines behavior that is not captured by other gateways. Expressions are used to determine the \nmerging and splitting behavior."

input: "<dataAssociation id=\"dataAssociation\" sourceRef=\"sourceId\" targetRef=\"targetId\" />"
output: "A Data Association is represented by a dotted line with a line arrowhead and is used to associate data (electronic or nonelectronic) with flow objects. Data Associations are used to show the inputs and outputs of activities"

input: "<dataInput id=\"dataInput\" name=\"Data Input\" />"
output: "A Data Input is an external data input for the entire process. It is a kind of input parameter."

input: "<dataObject id=\"dataObject\" name=\"Data Object\" />"
output: "Represents data or information used in the process. Data Objects provide information about what Activities require to be performed and/or what they produce, Data Objects can represent a singular object or a collection of objects. Data Input and Data Output provide the same information for Processes."

input: "<bpmn:dataObject id=\"DataObject_1\" name=\"DataObject\" />"
output: "A Data Object represents data used or generated within a process. It can be associated with tasks or events to show data dependencies."

input: "<dataOutput id=\"dataOutput\" name=\"Data Output\" />"
output: "A Data Output is the data result of the entire process. It is a kind of output parame"

input: "<dataStoreReference id=\"dataStore\" name=\"Data Store\" />"
output: "A Data Store is a place where the process can read or write data (e.g., a database or a filing cabinet). It persists beyond the lifetime of the process \ninstance."

input: "<endEvent id=\"endEvent\" name=\"End\" />"
output: "Represents the completion of a process or workflow.The End Event indicates where a path in the Process will end. A Process can have more than one end. The Process ends when all active paths have ended. End Events have no outgoing sequence flows."

input: "<bpmn:endEvent id=\"EndEvent_1\" />"
output: "An End Event marks the completion of a process or a subprocess."

input: "<eventBasedGateway id=\"eventBasedGateway\" name=\"Event-Based Gateway\" />"
output: "Represents a branching point that routes the flow based on incoming events. It is used for event-driven scenarios. The Event Gateway is always followed by catching events \nor receive tasks. The flow of the Process is routed to the subsequent event/task which happens first. When merging, it behaves like an Event Gateway."

input: "<exclusiveEventBasedGateway id=\"exclusiveEventBasedGateway\" name=\"Exclusive Event-Based Gateway\" />"
output: "Similar to an exclusive gateway, but it routes based on incoming events instead of conditions."

input: "<exclusiveGateway id=\"exclusiveGateway\" name=\"Exclusive Gateway\" />"
output: "Decides one path to take based on conditions. when splitting, routes sequence flow to only one of the outgoing branches, based on conditions. When merging, it awaits one incoming branch to complete before continuing the flow. The Gateway can be displayed with or without the ?X? marker, but the behavior is the same."

input: "<subProcess id=\"expandedSubProcess\" name=\"Expanded Sub-Process\" isExpanded=\"true\">"
output: " This attribute indicates that the sub-process is expanded, meaning all its details are fully visible within the main process diagram. It typically includes a name attribute to label the sub-process. Expanded sub-processes are used when you need to show all the internal activities and interactions of a subprocess without collapsing them."

input: "<exclusiveGateway id=\"gateway\" name=\"Gateway\" />"
output: "Represents a decision point in the process flow."

input: "<bpmn:exclusiveGateway id=\"Gateway_1\" />"
output: "An Exclusive Gateway is used to make exclusive choices in the process flow, allowing one path to be taken based on conditions."

input: "<inclusiveGateway id=\"inclusiveGateway\" name=\"Inclusive Gateway\" />"
output: "The Inclusive Gateway, when splitting, allows one or more branches to be activated, based on conditions. All active incoming branches must complete before merging."

input: "<intermediateEvent id=\"intermediateEvent\" name=\"Intermediate Event\" />"
output: "Represents an event that occurs between the start and end of a process or subprocess. It can trigger certain actions or transitions based on conditions. Intermediate events can have various types (e.g., timer, message, signal) based on their triggering mechanisms."

input: "<bpmn:intermediateCatchEvent id=\"IntermediateEvent_2\"> <bpmn:messageEventDefinition /></bpmn:intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "An Intermediate Event with a Message Catch event represents a point in the process where it waits for a specific message to arrive."

input: "<bpmn:intermediateEvent id=\"IntermediateEvent_1\" />"
output: "Intermediate Events indicate something that occurs or may occur during the course of the process, between Start and End. Intermediate Catching Events can be used to catch the event trigger and can be in the flow or attached to the boundary of an activity. Intermedi ate Throwing Events can be used to throw the event trigger"

input: "<lane id=\"lane\" name=\"Lane\" />"
output: "Groups and organizes elements within a pool.A Lane is a sub-partition within a Process, sometimes within a Pool, and will extend the entire length of the Process, either vertically or horizontally. Lanes are used to organize and categorize Activities"

input: "<bpmn:lane id=\"Lane_1\" name=\"Lane\" />"
output: "A Lane is used to categorize and organize BPMN elements within a pool. It helps to visually group related elements."

input: "<task id=\"taskWithLoop\" name=\"Task with Loop\"><multiInstanceLoopCharacteristics isSequential=\"false\" /></task>"
output: "A Loop Marker is used to represent an activity that will be executed multiple times until \nthe condition is satisfied. The condition can be validated either at the start or end of the \nactivtiy."

input: "<manualTask id=\"manualTask\" name=\"Manual Task\" />"
output: "A Manual Task is a task that is expected to be performed without the aid of any business \nprocess execution engine or application."

input: "<messageFlow id=\"messageFlow\" sourceRef=\"task1\" targetRef=\"task2\" />"
output: "A Message Flow is represented by a dashed line with an open arrowhead and is used to show the flow of messages between two \nseparate process participants (business entities or business roles) that send and receive them."

input: "<bpmn:messageFlow id=\"MessageFlow_1\" sourceRef=\"UserTask_1\" targetRef=\"IntermediateEvent_2\" />"
output: "A Message Flow is represented by a dashed line with an open arrowhead and is used to show the flow of messages between two \nseparate process participants (business entities or business roles) that send and receive them."

input: "<parallelEventBasedGateway id=\"parallelEventBasedGateway\" name=\"Parallel Event-Based Gateway\" />"
output: "Similar to a parallel gateway, but it routes based on incoming events, allowing multiple paths to be taken simultaneously.The Parallel Event Gateway is only used for starting a \nProcess. It is configured like a regular Event Gateway, but all of the subsequent events must be triggered before a new process instance is created."

input: "<parallelGateway id=\"parallelGateway\" name=\"Parallel Gateway\" />"
output: "Splits the flow into multiple parallel paths.The Parallel Gateway, when splitting, will direct the flow down all the outgoing branches. When merging, it awaits all the in branches to complete before continuing the flow."

input: "<pool id=\"pool\" name=\"Pool\" />"
output: "Represents a high-level container for a process.   A Pool is the graphical representation of a Participant in a Collaboration . It also acts as a ?swimlane? and a graphical container for partitioning a set of Activities from other Pools, usually in the context of B2B situations. A Pool MAY have internal details, in the form of the Process that will be executed. Or a Pool MAY have no internal details, i.e., it can be a \"black box.\""

input: "<bpmn:participant id=\"Participant_1\" name=\"Participant\" processRef=\"Process_1\" />"
output: "A Pool is used to group BPMN elements into separate participants in a collaboration diagram. It represents a participant in the process."

input: "<receiveTask id=\"receiveTask\" name=\"Receive Task\" />"
output: "A Receive Task is a simple task that is designed to wait for a message to arrive from an external participant (relative to the \nprocess)."

input: "<scriptTask id=\"scriptTask\" name=\"Script Task\"><script/></scriptTask>"
output:
"A Script Task is executed by a business process engine. The modeler or implementer defines a script in a language that 
the engine can interpret. When the task is ready to start, the engine will execute the script. When the script is completed, the 
task will also be completed.
"

input: "<sequenceFlow id=\"flow1\" sourceRef=\"startEvent\" targetRef=\"task\" />"
output: "A Sequence Flow is represented by a solid line with a solid arrowhead and is used to show the order (the sequence) in which activities will be performed in a process or choreography diagram."

input: "<bpmn:sequenceFlow id=\"SequenceFlow_1\" sourceRef=\"StartEvent_1\" targetRef=\"UserTask_1\" />"
output: "A Sequence Flow is represented by a solid line with a solid arrowhead and is used to show the order (the sequence) in which activities will be performed in a process or choreography diagram."

input: "<serviceTask id=\"serviceTask\" name=\"Service Task\" />"
output: "A task that is executed by a service or automated system."

input: "<startEvent id=\"startEvent\" name=\"Start\" />"
output: "Represents the beginning of a process or workflow.Start Events indicate the instance or initiation of a process or an Event Sub-Process and have no incoming sequence flow. A Process can have more than one Start Event, but an Event Sub-Process only have one Start Event."

input: "<bpmn:startEvent id=\"StartEvent_1\" />"
output: "A Start Event indicates the beginning of a process or a subprocess."

input: "<subProcess id=\"subProcess\" name=\"Subprocess\" />"
output: "Represents a subprocess within the main process."

input: "<subProcess id=\"subProcess\" name=\"Sub-Process\"><standardLoopCharacteristics /></subProcess>"
output: "A Sub-Process is a type of activity within a process, but it also can be ?opened up? to \nshow a lower-level process. This is useful for process decomposition or general process \norganization."

input: "<task id=\"task\" name=\"Task\" />"
output: "Represents a basic unit of work within a process.A Task is an atomic Activity that is included within a Process. A Task is \nused when the work in the Process is not broken down to a finer level of Process detail."

input: "<bpmn:serviceTask id=\"ServiceTask_1\" />"
output: "A Service Task is a task that uses some sort of service, which could be a web service or an \nautomated application."

input: "<bpmn:userTask id=\"UserTask_1\" />"
output: "A User Task is a typical ?workflow? task in which a human performer performs the task \nwith the assistance of a software application and could be scheduled through a task list \nmanager of some sort."

input: "<userTask id=\"userTask\" name=\"User Task\" />"
output: "A User Task is a typical ?workflow? task in which a human performer performs the task \nwith the assistance of a software application and could be scheduled through a task list \nmanager of some sort."

input: "<startEvent id=\"messageStartEvent\" name=\"Message Start Event\"><messageEventDefinition /></startEvent>"
output: "Initiates the process upon receiving a specific message."

input: "<startEvent id=\"timerStartEvent\" name=\"Timer Start Event\"><timerEventDefinition /></startEvent>"
output: "Starts the process based on a timer condition."

input: "<startEvent id=\"signalStartEvent\" name=\"Signal Start Event\"><signalEventDefinition /></startEvent>"
output: "Triggers the process upon receiving a specific signal."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"messageCatchEvent\" name=\"Message Catch Event\"><messageEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "Captures a specific message to proceed in the process."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"timerCatchEvent\" name=\"Timer Catch Event\"><timerEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "A Timer Event is always of catch type and used tosignify waiting for a specific time condition to evalu\u0002ate to true, which will start a Process, start an Event \nSub-Process, wait in the middle of a flow, or wait as a Boundary Event."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"signalCatchEvent\" name=\"Signal Catch Event\"><signalEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "Waits for and captures a specific signal. Catching Signal Events are used for receiving signals. They are a generic, simple form of communication and exist within pools (same participant), across pools (dif\u0002ferent participants), and across diagrams"

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"conditionalCatchEvent\" name=\"Conditional Catch Event\"><conditionalEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "Suspends the process until a specified condition is satisfied.Conditional Events are used to determine whether to start (or continue) only if a certain condition is true. Like the Timer Event, the Conditional Event can only exist as a catching event. "

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"linkCatchEvent\" name=\"Link Catch Event\"><linkEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "Awaits a link to be triggered before proceeding."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"multipleCatchEvent\" name=\"Multiple Catch Event\"><multipleEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "Captures multiple events concurrently. The Multiple Event is used to summarize several event types with a single symbol. The event is triggered if any one of those types is satisfied."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"messageThrowEvent\" name=\"Message Throw Event\"><messageEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Throws a message to trigger another process or participant."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"signalThrowEvent\" name=\"Signal Throw Event\"><signalEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Sends a signal to trigger another process or participant. Throwing Signal Events are used for sending signals. They are a generic, simple form of communication and exist within pools (same participant), across pools (different participants), and across diagrams."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"linkThrowEvent\" name=\"Link Throw Event\"><linkEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Throws a link event to trigger other parts of the process."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"escalationIntermediateThrowEvent\" name=\"Escalation Intermediate Throw Event\"><escalationEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Throws an escalation event to indicate an escalation in the process, typically used for exceptional or unexpected situations."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"compensationIntermediateThrowEvent\" name=\"Compensation Intermediate Throw Event\"><compensateEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Throws a compensation event to trigger the compensation of previously completed activities, commonly used in compensation processes to undo or mitigate effects."

input: "<endEvent id=\"messageEndEvent\" name=\"Message End Event\"><messageEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Represents the end of a process with a message."

input: "<endEvent id=\"terminateEndEvent\" name=\"Terminate End Event\"><terminateEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Terminates the entire process immediately."

input: "<endEvent id=\"escalationEndEvent\" name=\"Escalation End Event\"><escalationEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Marks the end of a process with an escalation event, typically used to indicate an escalation condition has been met."

input: "<endEvent id=\"errorEndEvent\" name=\"Error End Event\"><errorEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Indicates the end of a process with an error event, typically used when an error condition is encountered."

input: "<endEvent id=\"cancelEndEvent\" name=\"Cancel End Event\"><cancelEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Represents the termination of a process due to a cancellation event, often used for interrupting and stopping processes."

input: "<endEvent id=\"compensationEndEvent\" name=\"Compensation End Event\"><compensateEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Marks the end of a process with a compensation event, used for compensating activities upon process completion."

input: "<endEvent id=\"signalEndEvent\" name=\"Signal End Event\"><signalEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Indicates the end of a process with a signal event, commonly used to signal the completion of a process to other processes."

input: "<endEvent id=\"terminateEndEvent\" name=\"Terminate End Event\"><terminateEventDefinition /></endEvent>"
output: "Represents the immediate and forceful termination of an entire process.The Terminate End Event is the ?stop everything? event. When a Terminate End Event is reached, the entire process is stopped, including all parallel activities."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"messageBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Message Boundary Event\"><messageEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, triggered by a message."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"timerBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Timer Boundary Event\"><timerEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, triggered by a timer."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"signalBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Signal Boundary Event\"><signalEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, triggered by a signal."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"errorBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Error Boundary Event\"><errorEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, triggered by an error."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"cancelBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Cancel Boundary Event\"><cancelEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, used to cancel or interrupt."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"compensationBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Compensation Boundary Event\"><compensateEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, related to compensation."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"conditionalBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Conditional Boundary Event\"><conditionalEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Attaches an event to a task or subprocess, triggered by a condition."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"escalationBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Escalation Boundary Event\"><escalationEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "A throw Escalation Event will cause the escalation con\u0002ditions that will trigger the catch Event"

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"messageNonInterruptingBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Message Boundary Event (Non-Interrupting)\"><messageEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Triggered by a specific message but does not interrupt the ongoing task or subprocess; it occurs concurrently."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"timerNonInterruptingBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Timer Boundary Event (Non-Interrupting)\"><timerEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Triggered by a timer condition but does not interrupt the ongoing task or subprocess; it happens concurrently."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"signalNonInterruptingBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Signal Boundary Event (Non-Interrupting)\"><signalEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Triggered by a specific signal but does not interrupt the ongoing task or subprocess; it occurs concurrently."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"conditionalNonInterruptingBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Conditional Boundary Event (Non-Interrupting)\"><conditionalEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Triggered when a specified condition is met but does not interrupt the ongoing task or subprocess."

input: "<boundaryEvent id=\"escalationNonInterruptingBoundaryEvent\" name=\"Escalation Boundary Event (Non-Interrupting)\"><escalationEventDefinition /></boundaryEvent>"
output: "Triggered by an escalation event but does not interrupt the ongoing task or subprocess; it occurs concurrently."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"escalationIntermediateCatchEvent\" name=\"Escalation Intermediate Catch Event\"><escalationEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "An Escalation Event handles escalation conditions, trig\u0002gering the start of an Event Sub-Process or a Boundary \nEvent."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"errorIntermediateCatchEvent\" name=\"Error Intermediate Catch Event\"><errorEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output: "A catch Error Event is used to capture errors and to handle them. This event can only be used as the start an Event Sub-Process or as a Boundary Event. These \nevents can catch errors thrown by the throw Error Events or errors thrown by a BPM system or services used by the Process"

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"errorIntermediateThrowEvent\" name=\"Error Intermediate Throw Event\"><errorEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "A throw Error Event is used set an error to be handled. \nThis event can only be used as an End Event (i.e., never \nas an Intermediate Event)"

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"cancelIntermediateCatchEvent\" name=\"Cancel Intermediate Catch Event\"><cancelEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output:
"Cancel Events can only be used in the context of the 
transactions. The catch Cancel Events are used as 
Boundary Events for the transaction Sub-Process, and 
will trigger the roll back of the transaction (i.e., the 
Activities of the Sub-Process)."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"cancelIntermediateThrowEvent\" name=\"Cancel Intermediate Throw Event\"><cancelEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "Cancel Events can only be used in the context of the transactions. The throw Cancel Events are only used within a transaction Sub-Process."

input: "<intermediateThrowEvent id=\"multipleIntermediateThrowEvent\" name=\"Multiple Intermediate Throw Event\"><multipleEventDefinition /></intermediateThrowEvent>"
output: "The Multiple Event is used to summarize several event \ntypes with a single symbol. When this is event is \nreached, then all the event types are thrown."

input: "<intermediateCatchEvent id=\"parallelMultipleIntermediateCatchEvent\" name=\"Parallel Multiple Intermediate Catch Event\"><multipleEventDefinition /></intermediateCatchEvent>"
output:
"The Parallel Multiple Event is used to summarize several 
event types with a single symbol. The difference 
between this event and the Multiple Event is that the 
Parallel Multiple is only triggered if all of those types 
are satisfied"

input:

<bpmn:definitions xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:bpmn="http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/20100524/MODEL" xmlns:bpmndi="http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/20100524/DI" xmlns:dc="http://www.omg.org/spec/DD/20100524/DC" xmlns:di="http://www.omg.org/spec/DD/20100524/DI" id="Definitions_0ddnwte" targetNamespace="http://bpmn.io/schema/bpmn" exporter="bpmn-js (https://demo.bpmn.io)" exporterVersion="14.0.0">
  <bpmn:process id="Process_1j5483y" isExecutable="false">

    </bpmn:startEvent>

      <bpmn:incoming>Flow_0ioihfs</bpmn:incoming>

    </bpmn:task>

      <bpmn:incoming>Flow_1uvkwcu</bpmn:incoming>
    </bpmn:endEvent>
    <bpmn:sequenceFlow id="Flow_1uvkwcu" sourceRef="Activity_0urrygn" targetRef="Event_1wfk6mg" />
    <bpmn:sequenceFlow id="Flow_0ioihfs" sourceRef="Event_0rg2jdk" targetRef="Activity_0urrygn" />
  </bpmn:process>
  <bpmndi:BPMNDiagram id="BPMNDiagram_1">
    <bpmndi:BPMNPlane id="BPMNPlane_1" bpmnElement="Process_1j5483y">
      <bpmndi:BPMNShape id="Event_0rg2jdk_di" bpmnElement="Event_0rg2jdk">
        <dc:Bounds x="172" y="102" width="36" height="36" />
        <bpmndi:BPMNLabel>
          <dc:Bounds x="155" y="145" width="70" height="14" />
        </bpmndi:BPMNLabel>
      </bpmndi:BPMNShape>

      </bpmndi:BPMNShape>
      <bpmndi:BPMNShape id="Event_1wfk6mg_di" bpmnElement="Event_1wfk6mg">
        <dc:Bounds x="422" y="102" width="36" height="36" />
        <bpmndi:BPMNLabel>
          <dc:Bounds x="397" y="145" width="86" height="14" />
        </bpmndi:BPMNLabel>
      </bpmndi:BPMNShape>
      <bpmndi:BPMNEdge id="Flow_1uvkwcu_di" bpmnElement="Flow_1uvkwcu">
        <di:waypoint x="370" y="120" />
        <di:waypoint x="422" y="120" />
      </bpmndi:BPMNEdge>
      <bpmndi:BPMNEdge id="Flow_0ioihfs_di" bpmnElement="Flow_0ioihfs">
        <di:waypoint x="208" y="120" />
        <di:waypoint x="270" y="120" />
      </bpmndi:BPMNEdge>
    </bpmndi:BPMNPlane>
  </bpmndi:BPMNDiagram>
</bpmn:definitions>"
output: "A message will trigger the process to start"

input:
"<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<bpmn:definitions xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:bpmn="http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/20100524/MODEL" xmlns:bpmndi="http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/20100524/DI" xmlns:dc="http://www.omg.org/spec/DD/20100524/DC" xmlns:di="http://www.omg.org/spec/DD/20100524/DI" id="Definitions_0ddnwte" targetNamespace="http://bpmn.io/schema/bpmn" exporter="bpmn-js (https://demo.bpmn.io)" exporterVersion="14.0.0">
  <bpmn:process id="Process_1j5483y" isExecutable="false">
    <bpmn:startEvent id="Event_1oudkcc">
      <bpmn:outgoing>Flow_1b2jy1o</bpmn:outgoing>
      <bpmn:conditionalEventDefinition id="ConditionalEventDefinition_0bt5zla">
        <bpmn:condition xsi:type="bpmn:tFormalExpression" />

output: " The process starts and then executes activity 1. After \"Activity 1\" is performed, the process comes to an end. If a specific message event happens during the process of activity 1, the process flow splits into two flows. In one flow,  activity 1  is still carried out and then the flow processes to an end. Simultaneously, in the other flow, activity 2 is carried out in parallel with the other flow and then the flow processes to an end.  "

output: "The process \"Order-Parts\" starts with a \"Parts required\" event. After this event, there is an exclusive gateway that splits the process into two paths. In the first path, if there are \"Parts in stock\", the process continues with the \"Retrieve parts from storage\" task. After completing this task, the process ends with a \"Parts retrieved\" event. In the second path, if there are \"Parts out of stock\", the process continues with the \"Create purchase order\" task. After completing this task, there is another exclusive gateway that checks if the vendor is known.  If the vendor is not known, the process continues with the \"Create vendor\" task. If the vendor is known, no additional step is necessay. Afterwards, the paths converge again in a exclusive gateway. The process continues with the \"Order parts from vendor\" task. After completing this task, the process continues with the \"Receipt of goods\" task. Finally, the process ends with a \"Parts procured\" event."

output: "The process \"Order-Parts\" starts with a \"Parts required\" event. After this event, there is an exclusive gateway. Depending on whether there are parts in stock or not, two different paths can be followed. If there are parts in stock, the process continues with the \"Retrieve parts from storage\" task, followed by the \"Parts retrieved\" end event. This path represents the scenario when the required parts are already available in the storage. If there are no parts in stock, the process takes a different path. It continues with the \"Create purchase order\" task, followed by an exclusive gateway. At this gateway, it is determined whether the vendor is known or not. If the vendor is known, the process proceeds with the \"Order parts from vendor\" task, followed by the \"Receipt of goods\" task, and finally ends with the \"Parts procured\" event. If the vendor is not known, the process goes to another task called \"Create vendor\". After this task, the process continues with the \"Order parts from vendor\" task, followed by the \"Receipt of goods\" task, and ends with the \"Parts procured\" event. In summary, the \"Order-Parts\" process starts with the need for parts and then follows different paths depending on the availability of parts in stock and the knowledge of the vendor. It ends with the successful retrieval or procurement of the required parts."

output: "The flow of the Order-parts-process depends on the availability of parts in stock. If there are parts in stock, the process follows the path \"Parts\" in stock\". If there are no parts in stock, the process follows the path \"Parts out of stock\". Furthermore, the process depends on, if the vendor is known or not."

output: "Before you can order parts from a vendor, you have to check, if there are parts in stock. If there are parts in stock, you don't have to order parts from vendor. If the parts are out of stock, you have to create a purchase order. Afterwards you have to check wheter the vendor is known. If he is known you can directly order parts from the vendor. Otherwise, you first have to create a vendor."

output: "The process starts with receiving a pitch deck from a startup that is seeking investment. The received pitch deck is subjected to a quick scan. Then an assessment of the potential market leads to two possible paths.If the the Potential market is larger than 1 Billion Euros the pitch deck is put into the database for further consideration. If the potential market is not larger than 1 billion euros, the pitch deck is discarded, leading to an end of the process.  If the pitch deck is considered valuable, the startup is compared with others in the database. Then another assessment follows,  if the company has already invested in the startup's competitor, the pitch deck is discarded and ends the process.  If no investment has been made in the competitor, an email is written to schedule a meeting with the CEO of the startup.\nThen an assessment of the starup value is made. If the startup is considered valuable, a recommendation is made to the investment board. If the startup is not considered valuable, the pitch deck is kept in the database without further action."

output: "The deal_sourcing starts with a\"receive a pitch deck\" event. After this event, the pitch deck is quickly scanned. Then an exclusive gateway splits the process into two paths. If this company's Potential market is larger than 1 Billion Euros, the pitch deck is put into the database for further consideration. Another path is triggered if the potential market is not larger than 1 billion euros, the pitch deck is discarded, leading to an end of the process. In further consideration, if the pitch deck is considered valuable, the startup is compared with other startups in the database. Then another assessment follows,  if the company has already invested in the startup's competitor, the pitch deck is discarded and ends the process.  If no investment has been made in the competitor, an email is written to schedule a meeting with the CEO of the startup.\nThen an assessment of the startup value is made. If the startup is considered valuable, a recommendation is made to the investment board. If the startup is not considered valuable, the pitch deck is kept in the database without further action."

output: "Before scheduling a meeting with the CEO of the start-up, you need to first receive a pitch deck from the company and check if the potential market for the company is larger than 1 billion Euros. If so, you need to put the pitch deck into our database and then compare this company with companies in the database to make sure that we never invested in its competitors before. If so, then you can schedule a meeting."

output: "The cancer_treatment process is conducted by the hospital and starts with a start event and is followed by a decision point of checking whether chemotherapy should be performed. If not, this goes to a consult event and then the end of the process. If yes, this process follows by conducting a blood draw. Then a checking point divides the path into two paths. On one path,  if the patient should be examined, the flow goes to the medical examination process, when the examination faces an error, the infusion should be cancelled and end the process. In occasions without errors, the flow joins another path from the last decision point to an infusion decision point.  On the other path, when examination of the patient is not needed, the flow directly goes to the infusion decision point. at the infusion decision point, if the infusion is not needed, the process comes to an end. If the infusion is needed, the process flows to the infusion event when the infusion is conducted. If any error happens during the infusion process, the infusion should be interrupted and the process should end. If no error happens during the infusion, the process flows to an end."

output: "The cancer_treatment process is conducted by the hospital and starts with a start event.  After this event, there is an exclusive gateway.  Depending on whether chemotherapy should be performed. If not, a consult is performed and then the end of the process. If yes, a blood draw is conducted. Then a checking point divides the process nto two paths. On one path,  if the patient should be examined, the flow goes to the medical examination process, when the examination faces an error, the infusion should be cancelled and end the process. In occasions without errors, the flow joins another path from the last decision point to an infusion decision point.  On the other path, when examination of the patient is not needed, the flow directly goes to the infusion decision point. at the infusion decision point, if the infusion is not needed, the process comes to an end. If the infusion is needed, the process flows to the infusion event when the infusion is conducted. If any error happens during the infusion process, the infusion should be interrupted and the process should end. If no error happens during the infusion, the process flows to an end."

output: "The Dispatch_of _goods process is carried out in the Computer Hardware Shop by \"Warehouse\", \"Secretary\" and \"Logistics\". The process starts with the secretary shipping goods. After shipping goods, two parallel paths are carried out in the Secretary and Warehouse.  On the one hand, the warehouse packages goods and then converges with the other parallel path. On the other parallel path, the Secretary clarifies the shipment method and then a decision point determines the following action taken by the secretary. If it is a special sending, the secretary needs to get 3 offers from logistic companies and then select the logistic company and place the order. Then this path converges with the path in the warehouse. On the decision point, if it is not special sending, the secretary needs to write a package label. Here includes an inclusive gateway, if insurance is necessary, Logistics needs to insure the parcel in parallel when the secretary writes the package label. Once those two processes are done, it join the path in the Warehouse. After the converging point, the Warehouse prepares for picking up goods. After that, this process ends with the event \"shipment prepared\"."

output: "The credit scoring process is carried out by three participants, respectively  \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\", \"credit scoring (bank)\", and \"scoring service\".  The process of \" credit scoring (bank)\" starts with receiving a scoring request from \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\". Then \" credit scoring (bank)\" requests a credit score from \"scoring service\". Then a decision point follows if \"credit scoring (bank)\" receives a score from the \"scoring service\", it then sends the score to \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\" and ends the process with the scoring request handled. If \"credit scoring (bank)\" does not receive a score from the \"scoring service\", it needs to first report the delay to \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\" and then wait until receiving a credit score from the \"scoring service\". After that, \"credit scoring (bank)\" sends the score to \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\" and ends the process with the scoring request handled.\nThe process of \"scoring service\" starts with receiving a scoring request from \" credit scoring (bank)\". After that, the \"scoring service\" computes the credit score (level 1) and then sends the result to \"credit scoring (bank)\". Then a decision point follows, if the score is available, \"scoring service\"  ends the process, if the score is not available, \"scoring service\" computes the credit score (level 2) and then sends the credit score to  \"credit scoring (bank)\" which is waiting for the credit score after reporting delay to \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\". After that, \"scoring service\" ends the process with scoring request handled."

instruction: "How does the process handle situations where a credit score is not yet available?"

output: "When can you receive a credit score depends on which department you belong to. If you are in the \"credit scoring frontend (bank)\" and you requested the credit score, you will receive the score after the \"credit scoring (bank)\" requests a credit score from the \"scoring service\" and receives the credit score. \nIf you are in the \"credit scoring (bank)\", you will receive a credit score after the \"scoring service\"  computes the credit score (level 1) when the score is available. If the score is not available, you will receive the score after  \"scoring service\" computes the credit score(level 2)."

output:
"This resource process is carried out by the recourse clerk. This process starts with the event of probable recourse being detected. After that, a "check case" event should happen and then followed by a decision point. If the recourse is not possible, the recourse clerk should close the case and end the whole process with the case closed. If the recourse is possible, the recourse clerk should send a request for payment and then send a reminder. After that, an event-based gateway follows, which means the following action depends on what happens after the recourse clerk sends the reminder. 
If the disagreement letter is received, the clerk needs to check the reasoning. After checking the reasoning, the clerk needs to judge whether the reasoning is OK. if the reason is OK, the clerk needs to then close the case and end the process; if the reasoning is not OK, the clerk needs to hand over the case to the collection agency, After handing over, the process ends with the case open. 
Back to the the timepoint when the clerk sends a reminder, if the reminder is due, the clerk should hand over the case to the collection agency, After handing it over, the process ends with the case open. 
Another event trigger after sending out a reminder is the "Money received" event. If money is received after sending a reminder, the recourse clerk then makes a booking closes this process and ends the process."

output: "To end the process after receiving a disagreement letter after sending a payment reminder, a clerk needs to check the reasoning fro the disagreement. After checking the reasoning, the clerk needs to judge whether the reasoning is OK. if the reason is OK, the clerk needs to then close the case and end the process; if the reasoning is not OK, the clerk needs to hand over the case to the collection agency, After handing over, the process ends with the case open. "

    </bpmndi:BPMNPlane>
  </bpmndi:BPMNDiagram>
</bpmn:definitions>"
output: "You can end the process with the case open in two scenarios. One is when you receive a disagreement letter after sending the payment reminder, and the reasoning for the disagreement is not okay. In this case, you need to hand over the case to the collection agency and then end the process with the case open. The other scenario is when the payment reminder is due, then you can hand over the case to the collection agency and then end the process with the case open."

output: "After sending a reminder, the recourse clerk should act according to the following event. If the disagreement letter is received, the clerk needs to check the reasoning. If the reminder is due, the clerk should hand over the case to the collection agency. If money is received after sending a reminder, the recourse clerk then makes a booking closes this process and ends the process."

output:
"This issue authority letter process happens in Allianz commercial and envolves 3 parties, respectively initiators, approvers and underwriters. This process starts with the need of new authority letter from underwriter. After that, initiator creates authority letter draft using the online tool. Then Initiator need to preview the authority letter to check if all information is complete and accurate. If so, initiator needs to send message to approvers with the authority letter, asking for approval. If not, Initiator needs to edit the authority letter draft and the preview the draft again untill all information is correct, then initiator can send the authority letter to approvers. 
Then approvers receive the message. Here comes a decision point, If approvers  does not agree with the contends in authority letter, they need to change the state of the authority letter to rejected and then send message to communicate with initiator about what should be changed. receiving the message, initiator needs to edit authprity letter draft and then repeat the preview step untill all information is correct then sendds the authority letter to approvers. Only untill approvers aggree with the authority letter, will they change the state of the authority letter to approved.  
After the sate is changed to appproved, Initiator needs to send Authority letter to authority holder by using function in the tool. After that, underwriter needs to sign the authority letter and the send a message to send bakc the signed authority letter. 
Receiving the message, Initiator stores the signed authority letter in sharepoint and then ends this proess with authority letter isuued."

output: "The three key parties involved are initiators, approvers, and underwriters. Initiators create the authority letter draft, approvers review and approve it, and underwriters initiate the need for a new authority letter and also sign the final authority letter."

output: "If you are initiator and face the situation that the authority letter is rejected, you should communicate with approvers, after receiving the feedback from approvers, you should then edit the authority letter. After that, you should preview the authority and edit the authority letter untill all information is complete and correct. Then send the correct authority letter to approvers.\nIf you are a approver and you rejected the authority letter, you should then communicate with initiator about the authority letter."

output:
"This seld_service_restaurant process is composed of 3 processes that are conducted by 3 parties. Those processes are "food consumption" conducted by guests,  "order processing" conducted by employees, and the food preparation process conducted by the chef. Those 3 processes communicate and connect through message flow. 
The food consumption process starts with the condition that guests notice their hunger, and then they enter the restaurant. After that, they choose dishes and wait until it's their turn. Given the condition of the turn, guests then place the order. After that, they pay money and take a buzzer given by the employee. Then guests get the information from the buzzer that the meal is ready. Following that, they get a meal, eat a meal and finally end the process without being not hungry anymore.
The order processing process starts with the message event that employees receive the order from guests. After that employees enter the order into the POS system and then give related information to guests and collect money. Following that, employees set up a buzzer and then hand over the buzzer to guests. After all these actions, employees inform the chef about the order. When employees receive the information that meals are ready from the chef, they set off the buzzer.Thus the information that the meal is ready is delivered to guests. Then an event gateway follows, which means employees need to act according to what happens next. If employees get the information that the guests appear, employees need to then hand over the meal, and then end this process with the order processed. If employees wait for 5 minutes and guests don't show up, employees need to call the guest, repeat this wait for 5 minutes and call loop until guests appear.
The meal preparation process starts with getting information from employees about meals needed. After that, the chef prepares the meal, places the meal in the hatch and then informs employees. After all these, the chef ends the process with the meal prepared."

output: "After setting off the buzzer, guests get the information that the meal is ready. Employees should then act according to what happens next. If employees get the information that the guests appear, employees need to then hand over the meal to guests , and then end this process with the order processed. If employees wait for 5 minutes and guests don't show up, employees need to call the guest, repeat this wait for 5 minutes and call loop until guests appear."

output: "The precure_parts process happens inside the Supply. ltd and is carried out by 3 parties. They are respectively, \"Department\", \"Central purchasing\" and \"Approver\". The process starts with the parts required event in the department. After that, a decision point follows, if parts are in stock, the department retrieves parts from storage and then ends the process with \"Parts retrieved from storage\". If parts are out of stock, the department specifies and quantifies requirements and then completes a purchase order. The purchase order information is then stored in the ERP system.\nAfter that, the process flows to the central purchasing party. It gets purchase order information from the ERP system and continues the process from the department. It first checks the purchase order and then reaches a decision point. In the decision point, if the vendor is known, the process continues. If the vendor is not known, the central purchasing creates the vendor, stores the vendor information in the ERP system, and then continues with the process. After the decision point and relative action, central purchasing creates an order template from the purchase order and stores the order template in the ERP system. The central purchasing approves the purchasing order and also puts the approved purchase order into the ERP system. \nAfter all these actions, the process flows back to central purchasing. Following the process in approver, central purchasing first gets a receipt of goods and then ends the whole process with parts procured. If a delivery problem happens during the receipt of goods, the receipt of goods will be interrupted. Then, central purchasing adjusts the order status and then ends the process with cancellation due to a delivery problem."

instruction: "What happens if the required parts are in stock?"

output: "The decision point in central purchasing involves determining whether the vendor for these parts is already known or not. If the vendor is known, the process continues. If not, central purchasing creates the vendor and stores their information in the ERP system before proceeding with the process."

instruction: "What are the possible ends of the process, and under what circumstances do they occur?"

output: "The possible outcomes of the \"precure_parts\" process are as follows: If the parts required are in stock, parts will be retrieved from the storage and then the process ends. \nIf partes required are out of stock, parts need to be procured from vendors. If everything proceeds smoothly, the process concludes with central purchasing getting a receipt of goods, and the whole process ends with \"parts procured.\" If a delivery problem occurs during the receipt of goods, the process is interrupted. Central purchasing then adjusts the order status and ends the process with \"cancellation due to a delivery problem.\""

output:
"The underwriter_hiring process is carried out in "Allianz" and includes two parties, the HR and the underwriting department. It begins with the reception of the applicant's CV in HR part. After that, HR inputs key information of the applicant into the HR system. Next, a decision is made regarding the applicant's English language proficiency. If they speak English, the CV is forwarded to the underwriting department. If not, an email rejecting the candidate is sent, leading to an end of the process. 
After the CV being forward to the underwriting department, the process flows to the underwriting department. Within the underwriting department, the candidate's underwriting experience is evaluated. If they have the required experience, an email is sent to arrange an interview If not, a rejection email is sent, leading to an end of the process. After the interview, the process checks if the interview was satisfactory. If it was, an offer is extended to the candidate. If not, a rejection email is sent. After one of these action the process is end.

"
